summary:
I strive to bring change and solution-oriented impact to the high-tech sector, driven by curiosity, perseverance, growth, and ethical values. 

As a research fellow, I lead international projects on supercomputer simulations and software development at the intersection of high-tech HPC, data science innovation and astrophysics. My problem-solving approach combines attention to detail, systems thinking, modern agile methodologies, and collaboration-focused leadership.

- I am drawn to challenges and I love tackling problems that are thought unsolvable. Re-defining the state-of-the-art through innovative ideas underpins all my research and my vision for value-driven delivery. During my PhD, I became the point of contact for designing zoom-in hydrodynamic simulations within the Virgo Consortium, the largest international organisation for computational cosmology research.  During my 5-year experience, I developed software to extract novel insights from complex systems and presented at 9 international conferences, over 30 plenary meetings and in 7 technical reports.

- I lead research projects with teams in the Virgo Consortium, the world’s leading partnership in computational cosmology by combined h-factor, and I coordinate 4 projects using the UK’s top supercomputing facilities from DiRAC-STFC.

- I have mentored 100+ students, run 50+ programming workshops and communicated principles of agile working, data science and presentation skills to 2 award-winning groups of students (SARSTEM and DSI-Africa).

- I was fortunate to chair the student-run Astronomy Society at the University of Manchester. During my appointment, the Society featured in national events (BlueDot) and television (BBC), organised 100+ science outreach events and its member count surged by 400%.

My interests: 
Self-development books & educational resources (Bloomberg, Financial Times, The Economist) | Business, economics, investing | Coding projects & Machine-Learning | Alpinism, fitness, nutrition | Photography (awards for astronomical and landscape compositions) | Travelling & exploration.

projects.title: SWIFTzoom: a Python library for the agile analysis of zoom-in simulations
projects.description: The SWIFT simulation software is a unicorn in the computational cosmology sector, with users and science use cases growing daily. To align with the directives of FAIR software development, we developed SWIFTzoom, a Python library that provides the essential tools to analyse zoom-in hydrodynamic simulations. The library features a modular, agile and extensible design, built with state-of-the-industry software engineering best practices.

projects.title: Rotational kinetic Sunyaev-Zel’dovich effect in massive galaxy clusters
projects.description:
- Updated the predictions for the rotational kSZ signal expected from massive galaxy clusters in the MACSIS simulations over a range of redshifts. Working on the implications for the matter power spectra (2- and 3-point correlations) and mock observations using the NIKA-2 microwave camera.

- Developed reduction pipelines applicable to a wide range of simulation code outputs and set-ups: zoom-in and cosmological volumes, produced with GADGET-3. While being hosted on GitHub, I deployed the analysis package on several local servers where the datasets are stored and joined results by automated SSH port-forwarding.

- Preliminary results presented at the 2021 NIKA conference and paper in preparation.

projects.title: How do galaxy clusters form entropy cores?
projects.description:
- Led a collaboration project (Virgo Consortium) to investigate the entropy-core problem, a long-standing open question in astrophysics, as part of the PRACE-funded EAGLE-XL project. I assigned each member of the international team tasks to develop and report on during weekly meetings.

- Coordinated the research plan with separate Virgo projects running in parallel (COLIBRE, FLAMINGO).

- Produced a suite of zoom-in simulations and built a pipeline to generate the resolution-refined initial conditions (PANPHASIA, Fortran), running the full-physics model using numerical time-integration (SWIFT, C and MPI) and the post-processing using a halo-structure finder (VELOCIraptor, C++).

- Led the development of a novel masking tool for defining the halo’s Lagrangian domain in the initial conditions. Before refining the high-resolution mask, I introduced an algorithm for detecting topologically disconnected subsets of the Lagrangian region and then used Scipy’s space-filling tools to fill the gaps while minimising the amount of volume added to the original mask.

- Results presented at General Virgo conferences and paper accessible at https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2022arXiv221009978A/abstract.

- The code and data are open-source and freely accessible at  https://github.com/edoaltamura/entropy-core-problem

profile_positions.description:
I work at the Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics (JBCA), affiliated with the University of Manchester and the Department of Physics and Astronomy. My projects primarily involve massively parallel simulations of galaxy clusters, large-scale structures, and galaxies. Side projects include observational follow-ups of predictions from the simulations and analysis of observations of extragalactic sources.
I also collaborate with members of the Virgo Consortium, one of the world's top organizations for computational cosmology research, the Institute of Computational Cosmology (ICC) at Durham University and Leiden University.
Individual contributions include the physics of the kinetic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect, the entropy problem in cluster cores, modelling of relativistic jets from supermassive black holes using SPH, technical aspects of simulations codes, algorithms and their implementation using CPU-based (and soon GPU-hybrid) HPC facilities.

profile_positions.description:
Rapid Multispectral Photovoltaic Performance Mapping using Structured Light Illumination

Modern photovoltaics are designed to approach the theoretical thermodynamic limit of efficiency, known as Shockley-Queisser limit. This limit arises because, with a single band gap $E_g$, photons below this energy ($\hbar \omega < E_g$) are not absorbed, while photons above this energy loose their excess energy $\Delta E = \hbar \omega - E_g$ as thermal waste. Tandem cells, made of two or more cells with different band gaps, seek to bypass this limit. However, studying the spatial uniformity of such cells is challenging, as at least one critical interface is buried within the device.
This project seeks to develop an optical technique to inspect each layer based on compressive sensing. By projecting structured light patterns of different wavelenghts onto a tandem cell, the spatial distribution of current generation can be measured for each sub-cell. Furthermore, by sweeping voltage, a spatial map of fill-factor and/or efficiency may be produced.
In this project, the candidate will design a prototype device using a single board computer, integrated digital projector, designed PV acquisition board and a simple photovoltaic as prototype device. Building on proof-of-principle work carried out previously, the candidate will construct a fast, self-contained device for projection and acquisition of spatial data for photovoltaic applications.

Keywords: Multispectral, Efficiency, Photovoltaics, Semiconductors, Compressive Sensing.

profile_positions.title: Research consultant and mentor

profile_positions.description:
My appointment at Leiden Observatory is hosted by the computational cosmology and astrophysics group and funded by the HPC-Europa3 grant scheme, with myself as project PI. The focus of this collaboration is the development of the following aspects of the SWIFT hydrodynamical simulation code (https://swift.dur.ac.uk/):

- Adapting the MPI backend interface to rebalance the workload (tasks) across compute nodes in complex simulation designs, such as multi-resolution zoom-in initial conditions. While this feature will benefit my research on the core-entropy problem, it will also become a milestone for future high-resolution zoom-in simulations of massive galaxy clusters.

- Design and deployment of the spin-jets coupling in supermassive black holes at the centre of AGNs. This project is a follow up from my recent work on the core-entropy problem (paper in preparation) and leverages a new self-consistent BH jet model introduced by colleagues in the Virgo Consortium, but not yet tested in a full cosmological simulation setting.
